title: Student Exam Performances
text:
Welcome to the Student Exam Performances project website. This project analyzes the performance of students in exams using the Kaggle dataset. It focuses on understanding factors such as demographics, parental education levels, and test preparation, and how these correlate with exam scores.




library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)

title: Student Exam Performances
text:
The dataset contains the following columns:

gender: Student’s gender (male/female)
race/ethnicity: Race/ethnicity of the student
parental level of education: Parent’s education level
lunch: Type of lunch student received (standard/reduced)
test preparation course: Whether the student completed a test preparation course (none/completed)
math score: Score in math exam
reading score: Score in reading exam
writing score: Score in writing exam

title: Student Exam Performances
text:
library(tidyverse)
students <- read.csv(“data/StudentsPerformance.csv”)

title: About Page
text:
This website explores the performance of students in exams using the StudentsPerformance.csv dataset. The data provides insights into various factors that may affect student performance, including gender, race/ethnicity, parental education level, and more.


The objective of this project is to analyze and visualize the data to uncover patterns and insights into student performance. The following sections cover:

Home: Introduction to the website and what its about with examples and visuals.
Data Analysis: Methods used to analyze the data with visuals.
Sources: The origin of the data and its contents.
About: About the project and the author.




The dataset contains records for various students along with their scores in math, reading, and writing exams. It includes the following columns:

gender: Student’s gender (male/female)
race/ethnicity: Race/ethnicity of the student
parental level of education: Parent’s education level
lunch: Type of lunch (standard/reduced)
test preparation course: Whether the student completed a test preparation course (none/completed)
math score: Score in math exam
reading score: Score in reading exam
writing score: Score in writing exam




I’m Harshil Kurapati, a rising senior in highschool with a passion for data science. This project is part of my exploration into educational data and aims to provide valuable insights into factors affecting student performance.
You can find more about my work on GitHub or reach out to me via email at ckurapat@gmail.com.



This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp, where I learned essential skills in data analysis and visualization to tackle real-world challenges.

title: Student Exam Performances
text:
This website explores the performance of students in exams using the StudentsPerformance.csv dataset. The dataset includes information such as student demographics, parental education levels, and exam scores in various subjects.


The dataset contains the following columns:

gender: Student’s gender (male/female)
race/ethnicity: Race/ethnicity of the student
parental level of education: Parent’s education level
lunch: Type of lunch student received (standard/reduced)
test preparation course: Whether the student completed a test preparation course (none/completed)
math score: Score in math exam
reading score: Score in reading exam
writing score: Score in writing exam






library(tidyverse)
students <- read.csv(“data/StudentsPerformance.csv”)

title: Data Source and Cleaning
text:
The dataset used in this project is sourced from Kaggle’s “Students Performance in Exams” dataset. This dataset contains information about students’ demographics, parental education levels, lunch type, test preparation status, and exam scores in math, reading, and writing.

Link to Dataset: Kaggle - Students Performance in Exams




Before conducting the analysis, the dataset underwent several cleaning steps:

Handling Missing Values: Checked for missing values in all columns. For columns with missing data (e.g., parental education level), decisions were made based on the impact of missing values on the analysis. Missing values were either imputed or removed, depending on the context.
Data Transformation: Converted categorical variables (e.g., gender, race/ethnicity) into factors for easier analysis and visualization.
Outlier Detection: Identified potential outliers in exam scores using statistical methods (e.g., Tukey’s fences). Outliers were carefully examined and either removed or kept based on their impact on the overall analysis.





None: The dataset did not require the removal of entire observations. However, outliers in exam scores were removed to ensure the robustness of the analysis and visualizations.




For more details about this project, visit the About page.
